we've integrated with Route 53 our DNS service uh with something called health checks uh this this allows us to very
quickly react to uh application Level or uh infrastructure level failures uh in
your backend host and so uh this is going to increase uh your your reliability uh it means fewer uh
requests get sent to degraded instances or degraded application servers um and
then the second one is one that you're going to want to check out if you're running a multi uh a application
traditionally our load balancer has segregated traffic to azs and this has resulted in uh sometimes a number of
different problems it means you have to have the same amount of capacity in each availability Zone uh it means that uh if
you have uh a slow server or solow set of servers in one availability Zone some of your customers might be seeing slow
traffic While others might be seeing fast traffic if you turn on Cross Zone availability uh cross Zone load
balancing uh elb will automatically Route traffic across your availability zones to the best possible instance and
this will result in uh latency and availability improvements um and so one of the big things about this is that uh
we there's no cross Zone availability cost for that we we route that the most efficient way to your best available
application server so if you're running elb this is one I I highly suggest you check
out and then Amazon VPC is our virtual private Cloud um basically VPC was
originally built uh to provide the abstractions that customers who are connecting from a private data center

particular set of IP addresses to those instances and it provide very fine familiar uh networking abstractions to
the user uh but it also turns out that it provides uh increased uh functionality

uh changed our product in a way that's largely unnoticed by customers so so that customers are in fact running an
ec2 VPC without even knowing it and so as of I think April or May this year uh
the vast majority of new accounts created uh in AWS were Act created in
this mode that we call VPC for everyone uh vppc for everyone essentially creates a creates a VPC and configures the VPC
to look as though you're running in a classic ec2 environment so it basically opens up the edge firewall completely it
assigns public IP addresses by default to all your instances um it basically relies on your Security Group uh set up
to to manage connections between instances but what happens so so when you first approach ec2 uh or AWS you
don't see any difference from the experience you would have seen on EC the classic ec2 experience a year ago but
what changes is first of all the underlying technology uh in terms of uh how we're routing packets which is

decide that you want to take advantage of VPC at any time and so you can turn on that firewall you can decide to

uh we'll be providing guidance uh as well as uh tools to help you if you want to migrate into one of these new

permissions so you can say that uh Matt can terminate this instance uh but Joe
cannot and so that's a a much more fine grain permission scheme you can use specific resources IDs like an instance
ID or you can tag the resources for example uh you could tag all of your
resources in your production environment with the tag environment equals prod and all of your res resources in your test

test but he cannot change prod but Joe can change prod and so those sorts of uh
